emailColumn.title: Renova: Strategic Expansion into LATAM & MENA Markets

authorInfo.title: About the Author
authorInfo.description: Anastasiia Faizulenova is the Founder & CEO of Renova, a seasoned entrepreneur who successfully exited Checkme in 2023 after reaching breakeven. With expertise in insurtech and fintech sectors across CIS markets, she leveraged her domain knowledge and Spanish language skills to strategically expand into Latin America and MENA regions. Anastasiia designed Renova as an international-first company, focusing on SaaS solutions for insurance brokers in underserved markets.

keyTakeaways.title: Key Strategic Insights
keyTakeaways.description: Renova's expansion demonstrates how mature home market expertise can create competitive advantages in emerging markets. The company's success shows that systematic market research, cultural adaptation, and strategic resource allocation are crucial for international expansion. Key lessons include: leveraging existing domain knowledge for global competitiveness , conducting thorough desk research while preparing for cultural nuances, adopting lean hiring practices until product-market fit is established, and choosing markets with favorable regulatory environments and growth potential . The case highlights that founder-led sales are essential in early stages, and building local partnerships accelerates market entry.

emails.subject: From Checkme Exit to Global Vision: Why We Chose International from Day One
emails.body: You asked about what first triggered our international expansion efforts and what motivated me to look beyond the CIS market. ğŸ¤” The catalyst came in 2023 when Checkme (my previous venture) reached breakeven. At that point, I decided to sell the company and create Renova ğŸš€, which was designed for international markets from the beginning. The decision to go international rather than launching another venture in the CIS was driven by several considerations. I determined that the smartest move was to continue in insurtech, leveraging my existing expertise and knowledge. ğŸ§  What many don't realize is that home insurtech and fintech sectors are actually quite mature and advanced compared to many markets globally â€” even some Western countries. This meant I could compete globally based on my specialized knowledge rather than starting from scratch in a new industry. It made sense to focus on what I knew best, where I had proven expertise that could translate internationally. ğŸ’ª We conducted our own research to identify promising regions, ultimately landing on Latin America (LATAM) ğŸŒ and the Middle East and North Africa (MENA) ğŸ•Œ as our primary targets.

emails.subject: Market Selection Masterclass: How We Chose LATAM & MENA
emails.body:
You asked about which markets we considered initially and what parameters we evaluated during our selection process. ğŸ¤”

After careful analysis, I settled on LATAM and selected MENA countries as our primary targets â€” specifically Mexico ğŸ‡²ğŸ‡½, Colombia ğŸ‡¨ğŸ‡´, Chile ğŸ‡¨ğŸ‡± and Dubai ğŸ‡¦ğŸ‡ª. Our evaluation included several key parameters:

â€¢ Number of insurance brokers in each region ğŸ‘¥
â€¢ Presence of digital competitors ğŸ’»
â€¢ Openness to innovation ğŸš€
â€¢ My familiarity with the local language ğŸ—£ï¸

LATAM presented particularly compelling opportunities. For example, insurance penetration in the region is only around 2.5% of the population (compared to 11% in Spain ğŸ‡ªğŸ‡¸). While initially this might seem discouraging, we noticed the market had grown to 3% in just two years â€” representing a 30% increase! ğŸ“ˆ This rapid growth signaled significant potential.

Two factors made LATAM especially attractive:

â€¢ A clear merger wave starting in our industry ğŸŒŠ
â€¢ A broker-dominated sales model (unlike home, where insurers sell directly) ğŸª

In Mexico alone, there are approximately 80,000 brokers selling essentially the same policies from the same insurers. This intense competition means brokers desperately need value propositions to differentiate themselves â€” creating perfect conditions for our SaaS solution. ğŸ’¡

We also evaluated existing solutions (finding about 20 SaaS competitors, some with recent funding) and regulatory environments. We prioritized markets with low regulatory barriers (avoiding GDPR-like regulations or expensive licensing requirements). ğŸ“‹

My language skills were another consideration. I already knew Spanish at what I'd call a "Catalonian Spanish" level â€” enough to communicate but also enough to occasionally annoy Mexicans with my accent! ğŸ˜… I had studied Spanish at university, which gave me a foundation, though I wouldn't have become truly fluent without practice. This language capability made LATAM particularly accessible.

Using similar criteria, we also identified opportunities in the Middle East, specifically Dubai. ğŸ•Œ

emails.subject: Market Research on a Budget: Our Desk Research Strategy
emails.body:
You asked about our research methodology and how we gathered market data for our expansion decisions. ğŸ¤”

Our approach was predominantly desk research due to budget constraints in the early stages. We relied on several sources:

â€¢ Reports from major consulting firms ğŸ“‹
â€¢ Government data (for example, Mexico maintains a public registry of insurance brokers) ğŸ›ï¸
â€¢ Industry publications and market analyses ğŸ“°

We developed a structured evaluation process, first assessing feasibility on a 1-10 scale for each potential market, then estimating market size and potential revenue. For instance, in Mexico, we calculated that capturing just 5-8% of the market could translate to approximately $20M in ARR! ğŸ’°

We looked at markets worldwide but systematically ruled out over-regulated regions like the United States ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸, Europe ğŸ‡ªğŸ‡º, and parts of Asia where entry barriers were prohibitively high. We also eliminated markets where policy values were too low to support our SaaS model â€” for example, in Indonesia ğŸ‡®ğŸ‡©, policies typically cost around $200 per year versus $2,000 in Mexico, making our value proposition less compelling.

After a year of operations, we found that our hard data research (broker counts, policy prices, market sizes) was largely accurate. âœ… However, cultural nuances proved more challenging to anticipate through desk research alone. For example, understanding that Mexicans culturally tend to avoid saying "no" directly â€” instead offering polite but noncommittal responses â€” was something we could only fully grasp through immersion. ğŸ¤ These soft factors around sales tactics and business relationship development required local experience to navigate effectively.

highlight.description: Research is like studying for a test vs. actually taking it! ğŸ“ Anastasiia could find all the numbers online - how many brokers, what prices, market sizes - and those were mostly right! âœ… But the tricky part was people stuff - like learning that Mexicans don't like to say "no" directly, so they say "maybe" instead. ğŸ¤ It's like knowing all the rules of soccer âš½ but not understanding that players have different styles and team personalities. You can't Google "how do Mexican business people really think?" - you have to experience it yourself! ğŸŒ®

emails.subject: Building Global Teams: Our International Go-to-Market Playbook ğŸŒ
emails.body: You asked about our team structure and go-to-market strategy for international markets. ğŸ¤” Renova was international by design from day one. ğŸŒ Our team structure assigned responsibilities based on functional roles rather than geography â€” CEO, local managers, CFO, legal, customer success, sales, and product all had defined international responsibilities. For our initial expansion, we pursued parallel launches in Dubai ğŸ‡¦ğŸ‡ª and Mexico ğŸ‡²ğŸ‡½, though we saw revenue materialize faster in Dubai (within 2 months âš¡ compared to 8 months in Mexico). While our product team remained centralized to maintain consistency, our go-to-market strategies differed significantly between regions. In Dubai, we employed a direct sales approach where I personally led product demonstrations. We engaged a high-ranking local lead manager from a top brokerage to help us build relationships and accelerate outreach. ğŸ¤ Our first international hire was on the product side. In the early stages, I handled most other functions (legal, finance) myself or with the assistance of GPT. ğŸ¤– I've found that hiring non-product roles too early often creates inefficiencies before product-market fit is established. For sales specifically, we initially avoided local hires in Mexico. My philosophy is that until product-market fit is proven, only founders can effectively drive early adoption. The passion, knowledge, and ability to make on-the-spot decisions are crucial in those early conversations. ğŸ’ª Later, as we began scaling, we added local sales representatives. To motivate Mexican partners, we offered equity (typically 2% vesting over specific milestones) ğŸ“ˆ and emphasized our product differentiation compared to competitors. The key factor in securing these partnerships wasn't just the commercial terms â€” it was their genuine belief in the product and its potential. We used the same product deck for all partners initially, though we customized commercial terms (equity arrangements, etc.) during later discussions. Our go-to-market budget was approximately $600,000 ğŸ’°, allocated to figure out what approaches would work best in our target markets. This included event participation and building partner networks.

highlight.title: Founder Power: Why Only You Can Sell Your Baby
highlight.description: Imagine trying to get someone else to sell your homemade cookies! ğŸª They might know the recipe, but they didn't stay up all night perfecting it. That's why Anastasiia insisted only founders should do early sales. When you create something, you have special magic âœ¨ - you know every detail, you're super passionate, and you can make quick decisions on the spot! It's like the difference between a parent talking about their kid vs. a babysitter - the love and knowledge just hits different! ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ‘©â€ğŸ‘§â€ğŸ‘¦ Once the product works well, then you can teach others to sell it too.

emails.subject: Learning the Hard Way: Our Biggest International Expansion Mistakes
emails.body: You asked about the operational challenges we faced and lessons learned during our international expansion. Looking back, there are several things I would improve about our market entry approach. ğŸ¤” â€¢ Faster local hiring: We should have established a Mexico-based agent sooner to navigate local complexities ğŸ‡²ğŸ‡½ â€¢ Leaner legal approach: We made an expensive mistake hiring in-house legal counsel based in Chicago, which wasn't necessary at our stage âš–ï¸ğŸ’¸ â€¢ Simplified entity structure: We created unnecessary legal entities and registrations that could have been avoided or deferred ğŸ“‹ â€¢ More aggressive partner network development: We could have leveraged our early partners for referrals more effectively ğŸ¤ â€¢ Better peer collaboration: We should have learned more from companies like Bitrix24 and AmoCRM about scaling internationally ğŸŒ Beyond these strategic adjustments, we encountered significant cultural and operational learning curves: â€¢ Language immersion: I found myself eventually dreaming in Spanish and understanding Shakira's lyrics without translation ğŸµ â€” this level of immersion expanded my thinking and cultural awareness in unexpected ways â€¢ Management adaptation: We had to adjust leadership styles significantly across markets. For example, deadline management in Mexico required a softer approach compared to other regions ğŸ•°ï¸ â€¢ Talent assessment: We learned which local schools and backgrounds produced the best talent for different roles, which helped refine our hiring approach ğŸ“ â€¢ Customer success transformation: Our reactive customer success model that worked elsewhere failed completely in Mexico â€” we had to shift to a more proactive, hands-on approach with significant hand holding ğŸ¤— Our real goal wasn't tied to specific revenue figures but rather validating product-market fit â€” securing even one paying client who genuinely valued our solution. ğŸ¯

emails.subject: Smart Resource Allocation: Build vs. Buy in Global Markets
emails.body:
You asked about how we allocated resources between markets and our approach to outsourcing versus building in-house capabilities. ğŸ¤”

Our strategic approach to resource allocation evolved as we gained operational experience. After launch, we decided to outsource several functions including legal support ğŸ“, public relations ğŸ“¢, and customer service overflow ğŸ“. This approach provided us with greater flexibility compared to full-time hires, particularly during our scaling phase.

I've found that outsourcing offers better hourly accountability â° and allows us to scale services up or down based on actual needs. This proved especially valuable as we navigated the different growth rates between our Dubai ğŸ‡¦ğŸ‡ª and Mexico ğŸ‡²ğŸ‡½ operations.

While our product team remained centralized to maintain consistency ğŸ”§, we've been deliberate about which functions to build in-house versus outsource. Early on, I handled many functions myself or with GPT assistance ğŸ¤– rather than building large teams prematurely. This lean approach allowed us to maintain flexibility while we validated our business model across different markets.

For anyone considering international expansion, I'd recommend carefully evaluating which functions truly need to be in-house versus those that can be effectively outsourced, especially during the early validation stages. Building too much infrastructure too soon can create financial strain before revenue streams are established. ğŸ’°

highlight.description: Think of building a team like assembling furniture! ğŸª‘ Sometimes you need the flexibility to add or remove pieces quickly. Anastasiia discovered that outsourcing was like having modular furniture - she could add more customer service when Dubai was growing fast, then reduce it when things slowed down. With full-time employees, it's like having furniture bolted to the floor - hard to change! ğŸ”§ Plus, outsourced people often work harder per hour because they know the work might not last forever.
